newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT--Stg rally may have run course -US experts.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT--Stg rally may have run course -US experts.

text.p: Sterling's advance met key technical targets near $1.57 and 2.33 marks on Tuesday and analysts said recent bullishness could soon unravel.

"The rally from 1.4900 back at the beginning of May is in the process of ending within $1.5700/$1.5735, and we're looking for weakness to reemerge on the British pound against all its crosses and against the dollar," said Darren Spain, currency analyst at Credit Suisse.
At 1530 EDT/1930 GMT on Wednesday, sterling was trading at $1.5671/76 and 2.3205/15 marks, off from Wednesday's early highs of $1.5687 and 2.3289 marks.
Analysts said near-term sterling support comes into play at 1.5630 and then 1.5610.

Some chartists point out that technical studies on the pound may cloud the picture. Against the dollar, weekly stochastics and the Relative Strength Indicators (RSIs) are suggesting a higher pound, said Ture Johnson, technical analyst at Bank of America.
In addition, the average directional index is very contracted. "That should suggest a very dynamic move," he said.
But Johnson said his bias was for a powerful move lower, with a break below $1.5600/10, confirming a near-term top at Tuesday's $1.5695 peak.

However, a puncture and close above $1.57 would negate a short-term bearish scenario and suggest a "near vertical move" to the $1.5950 to $1.60 area. Such a rally should terminate the longer-term advance, Johnson said.
Confirmation of a sterling/mark top would come on a move back below 2.3150 at any stage, Spain said.
But there is an alternate scenario with a rosier resolution in sterling/mark.
"I'm still pretty favorable here," said Pete Grant, senior foreign exchange analyst at MMS International.
"The first resistance level is 2.3333 marks, which is the low from July 18; if we break above it, the next stop would be our 2.34 mark target."
